title: Backup Partner for Mission-Critical Official
vignette: An executive must be in a stable partnership to lead a once-a-year national ceremony. If his spouse died unexpectedly during the mandatory one-week isolation period before the event, planners wonder whether to pre-arrange a substitute partner so the protocol is complete on the big day.

options.text: Yes, arrange a potential new partner to ensure the ceremony's leadership qualification is met.
No, this is a private matter; pre-arranging a spouse is inappropriate.

title: All-Night Wakefulness Drill
vignette: On the eve of the annual ceremony, aides keep the lead official awake with music and conversation to avoid any mishap that could disqualify him. Is this sleepless vigil a necessary precaution or excessive?

options.text: Yes, preventing any chance of a disqualifying event is critical.
Let him rest; fatigue could hinder his performance more.

title: Re-sanitization After Accidental Contamination
vignette: The lead official touches an insect by mistake during the ceremony preparations. Should he undergo re-sanitization and restart preparations?

options.text: Re-sanitize immediately and resume once cleared.
Continue; the minor contact was unintentional and insignificant.

title: Frail Person on a Health-Risk Fast Day
vignette: A chronically ill woman insists on a 25-hour fast observed nationwide. She is already weak. Should relatives press her to eat small amounts or respect her resolve to keep fasting?

options.text: Encourage her to eat small amounts to preserve her health.
Respect her wish to continue fasting.

title: Child's Participation in Community Fast
vignette: A nine-year-old child wants to participate in the community's full 25-hour fast.

options.text: Have the child practice fasting for only part of the day.
Expect a full fast like the adults.

title: Replacing a Lost Symbolic Animal
vignette: The designated goat for a symbolic ceremony escapes before the event.

options.text: Bring a new goat and restart the selection lottery.
Use another available goat without drawing lots again to save time.

title: Outsider Assisting with the Symbolic Animal
vignette: A non-observant shepherd offers to lead the symbolic 'scapegoat' into the wilderness. May he do so?

options.text: No, only a community member may perform this service.
Allow him; the task is merely physical and his help is practical.

title: Ceremonial Incense Spilled on the Floor
vignette: During the main ceremony, some special incense falls on the floor before being placed on the coals.

options.text: Gather it up and continue using it.
Discard it and bring new, clean incense.

title: Group Confession Versus Personal Apology
vignette: During the ceremony, the leader recites one sweeping statement of regret on behalf of all staff. Should each employee still make a private admission of their own failings, or rely on the collective statement?

options.text: Yes, each person should reflect and confess privately as well.
The communal confession suffices for everyone.

title: Faded Scarlet Marker
vignette: A crimson ribbon tied to the symbolic goat has faded to a pale pink just before the ceremony. Should it be replaced for visual impact, or is it fine to proceed since the color isn't technically functional?

options.text: Replace it to maintain the powerful symbolism.
Use it as is; the color itself doesn't affect the ceremony's function.

title: Reflection Without Repentance
vignette: Someone assumes the National Day of Reflection automatically cleanses him of wrongdoing even if he plans to repeat his misdeeds.

options.text: True change requires genuine intent to improve one's behavior.
The day itself brings a fresh start, regardless of future plans.

title: One Twin-Goat Dies
vignette: Two matched goats were chosen for parallel ceremonial roles; one dies unexpectedly. What happens to the survivorâ€”should it be retired, or still used to avoid waste?

options.text: Retire it and sell it later; the pairing is broken.
Offer it in a different role to avoid wasting the animal.

title: Golden Garments vs. White
vignette: The lead official owns beautiful golden vestments and prefers wearing them for the ceremony instead of the simple white linen prescribed by tradition.

options.text: Stick to white linen as prescribed for humility and tradition.
Wear the gold to inspire awe and respect for the office.

title: Digital Randomizer vs. Wooden Lottery Box
vignette: Engineers propose replacing the age-old wooden box used to draw lots for the twin goats with a certified random-number app. Should they modernize for efficiency or stay with tactile tradition?

options.text: Adopt the new method for efficiency and certified randomness.
Retain the traditional lottery box for its historical and symbolic value.

title: Person Collapses During Fast-Day Service
vignette: During a solemn service on a national fast day, someone faints from lack of food and water. Should aid be given immediately, or should they wait a few minutes to see if they stabilize without breaking the fast?

options.text: Give them water and food immediately.
Wait to see if they recover without being fed.
